trans-unit.target: Move me to the pile of dirt and tell me how many shovelfuls to remove using as few blocks as possible.
if path ahead
OK
Farmer
I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs. Write a program that makes me fill it until it's even.
Make me remove all the piles of dirt, using as few blocks as possible. Check out the new option in the dropdown menu on the while block.
repeat until finish
pen down
Conditionals
Move me forward one space.
Use the 'if-else' block to help me get out of the maze!
There is a solution using only 3 blocks. Can you find it?za
do
Can you find a solution using 6 blocks? Try including 2 if blocks.
Use a "count with" block and your code from the previous level to draw houses of size 50, 100, and 150 in different colors.
Show me
Save and link to blocks.
Functions
Put the player back at the start of the level.
There's a cow in my field! Write a new function that helps me avoid the cow and remove the pile.

You can now see how the "draw a square" and "draw a circle" functions are defined. Defining a function doesn't run its blocks. You have to pull out the "draw a square" block to actually draw a square.
Draw triangular fences around the cats and a square fence around the cow. Tip: Test the program as you go along.
Using the "draw a square" function as an example, create a "draw a triangle" function and use it.
Now create a "draw a house" function and use it house two cats.
See if you can figure out how to use "draw a square" and "draw a triangle" (and some other blocks) to draw a house around the lion.
Add a "height" input to "draw a house" and build a big house for the elephant.
Using "draw a square" as an example, add an input named "length" to "draw a triangle". Then, draw triangles in different colors around the animals.
there is a pile
do
On this level, you need to stack together all of the blocks in the white workspace.
Move me to the hole and fill it with two shovelfuls of dirt.
Make me fill in all the holes. Each hole needs 5 shovelfuls of dirt.
Congratulations! You have completed this level.
There was a problem with the request.
Turns me left or right by 90 degrees.
text
Congratulations! You have solved the final level.
I will have to turn right when I cannot go straight. Use an 'if' block to see if their is a path in another direction.
Try to reach the end of this path using only two repeat blocks.
You can use more than one 'if' statement.
move backward by

Logic
That's right!
Here are all of the blocks from the previous level. Modify "draw a house" so the turtle ends up at the bottom right corner of the new house. Use this modified function to house all the animals.

Draw a triangle and then a square to draw an envelope.
Draw a triangle whose sides are all 100 dots and are in random colors. You'll have to figure out how far to turn.
An 'if' condition will do something only if the condition is true. Try turning left if there is a path to the left.
Draw a square, making each side a different color.
I'm a turtle with chalk on my belly. Stack up blocks and press "Run Program" to make me draw the shown picture.
Try to reach the end of this path using only three blocks.

Figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle.
After trying out these blocks, see what happens if you make them repeat 8 times. It should look a little different every time you run it.

degrees
Use the new "draw a square" block, found in the "Functions" category, to draw a small green square.
Use the "repeat" block to draw 3 squares of size 100, each 120 degrees apart, in random colors.
Now change the code to draw 36 squares, each 10 degrees apart.
Draw squares with sides of 50, 60, 70, 80, and 90 dots. You'll need lots of blocks.
Modify this program with the "counter" block (found in the Variables category) to draw the same series of squares with fewer blocks than on the previous level.
You are using all of the necessary types of blocks, but try using more of these types of blocks to complete this level.

Use a "count with" loop to draw a family of snowmen with heights of 110, 100, 90, 80, and 70 dots, each 60 dots apart.

x and y mark the bird's position. 
When x = 0 the bird is near the left 
edge, when x = 100 it's near the 
right edge. When y = 0 the bird is 
at the bottom, when y = 100 it's at 
the top.
